profileText: A Representative from New Hampshire; born in Gilmanton, Belknap County, N.H., June 16, 1782; attended the local academy in Gilmanton; studied law; was admitted to the bar in 1807 and practiced in Farmington, N.H.; member of the State house of representatives in 1813; served in the State senate 1820-1825; elected as an Adams candidate to the Nineteenth Congress (March 4, 1825-March 3, 1827); resumed the practice of law; died in Farmington, N.H., January 11, 1856; interment in Farmington Cemetery.

researchRecord.name: In the Levi Woodbury Family Papers, ca. 1638-1914, 16 linear feet.
researchRecord.description: Persons represented include Nehemiah Eastman. An inventory is available in the library.

researchRecord.name: 1829, 2 pages.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Nehemiah Eastman to Daniel Webster written on December 14, 1829. In the letter, Eastman writes about terms of land deal being considered, and how the President's message would have been better if he had left Mr. Clay, the Bank, and the Constitution alone.

researchRecord.name: In the Charles and Levi Woodbury Papers, 1833-1894, 0.5 linear foot.
researchRecord.description: Other authors include Nehemiah Eastman. A finding aid is available in the repository.
